alignments.summary: Provides a transparent view into which overlays are active.
alignments.submission_title: Shared Tray Protocol for Coordinated Overlay Interfaces
alignments.submission_overview:
I propose the development of a browser-level interface protocol that allows multiple overlays (e.g. assistants, wallets, chat tools) to register themselves into a shared, user-configurable tray, typically anchored in the lower-right corner of the screen. This would support coexistence of decentralized tools, prevent UX collisions, and empower users to customize their digital environment without friction.

Overlays would be able to:
- Register a “startup icon” and metadata (name, role, permissions)
- Indicate availability or priority
- Respect a shared system for tray placement and visibility
- Defer to user preferences in display and ordering

Users could:
- Configure which overlays are pinned or expanded
- Access others on demand via an expandable tray
- Rely on consistent placement and behavior across sites and browsers

Next Steps: I suggest forming a W3C Community Group to define an open standard for overlay registration and tray coordination. This standard could help browsers and web apps harmonize decentralized UI layers, supporting both open innovation and excellent UX.

This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
clarifications.clarification: Trust signals are transparent, but interpretation is decentralized across pluralistic providers.

clarifications.title: Digital Assertions as Verifiable Claims
clarifications.why_it_matters: Structural transparency improves trust and traceability beyond interface-level user feedback.
clarifications.submission_title: Enabling Machine-Readable Meaning through the Semantic Web
clarifications.submission_overview: This submission revisits the seminal 2001 vision of the Semantic Web, proposing its relevance and expanded applicability to modern decentralized meta-systems. It explores how the foundational architecture of the Semantic Web—built on distributed knowledge representation, interoperable ontologies, and machine-readable logic—prefigures the infrastructure needed for scalable, composable, and user-aligned digital environments. The submission identifies alignment with multiple Desirable Properties, especially regarding knowledge portability, participatory governance, and ethical agentic systems. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
clarifications.clarification: RDF triples with URIs and cryptographic signatures render claims verifiable by humans and machines.

clarifications.title: Algorithmic Disinformation as a Structural Risk
clarifications.why_it_matters: Without verifiable origin and provenance metadata, even informed users can be misled. Transparency is not optional—it's foundational for democratic digital spaces.
clarifications.submission_title: The Algorithmic Collapse: Reclaiming Humanity in the Age of AI Slop
clarifications.submission_overview: This submission critiques the current trajectory of internet culture, shaped by a deluge of AI-generated content that mimics human creativity without its soul. It raises alarms about the degradation of trust, the erosion of digital authenticity, and the weaponization of engagement algorithms. It also highlights the need for systemic reevaluation: how we value creative labor, what constitutes "real" content, and the risks of unchecked AI proliferation in social, artistic, and journalistic domains. The human internet is not dead—but it's under siege. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
clarifications.clarification: The submission identifies that AI-generated content is not merely noise but a potentially coordinated mechanism for manipulation. This includes bot networks masquerading as genuine engagement to influence public discourse or even geopolitical narratives.

extensions.title: Contextual Verifiability via Bridges
extensions.why_it_matters: Information can no longer stand alone — verifiability emerges through relational framing and traceable provenance.
extensions.submission_title: Bridges, Synaptic Web, and Universal Maps: Toward a Cognitive Meta-layer
extensions.submission_overview: This multi-part proposal outlines an architectural evolution of the web through three interconnected primitives: 1) Bridges as first-class web infrastructure, 2) The Synaptic Web as an adaptive, evolving collective intelligence, and 3) Universal knowledge maps for navigation, learning, and sensemaking. Together, these ideas transform the Meta-layer into a dynamic scaffold for contextual intelligence, verifiable information, and community co-creation. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Bridges link claims to evidence and alternative views, making trust-building a structural property of web knowledge.

extensions.title: Explainable Mediation Cues
extensions.why_it_matters: Builds trust in AI by making its moderation actions socially intelligible and inspectable.
extensions.submission_title: Cultivating Trust in AI-Assisted Online Conversations
extensions.submission_overview: This submission proposes a values-based framework for moderation, reputation, and friction in AI-mediated online discourse. Instead of punitive moderation, the system introduces soft interventions such as modulated visibility and reflection cues. These tools promote respectful, legible, and community-aligned interactions. The design treats moderation as a participatory, adaptive mechanism shaped by community values. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: AI interactions should include interpretable indicators of why and how moderation is occurring.

extensions.title: Versioning and Edit Trails in Navigational Layers
extensions.why_it_matters: Supports epistemic integrity and collaborative governance.
extensions.submission_title: Navigator User Interfaces (NUI) as a Coordination Layer for a Post-Search, Post-Feed Web
extensions.submission_overview: This submission introduces Navigator User Interfaces (NUIs) as a new standard for customizable, shareable navigation tools across web-based tasks, educational flows, and collaborative work. NUIs propose a federated ecosystem of navigation frameworks allowing pluralistic learning, interaction, and AI-guided exploration, grounded in a shared regular panel. This enables remixable workflows while supporting agency, privacy, transparency, and ethical alignment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Track and display modifications to shared paths and flows.

extensions.title: Secure Whistleblower Infrastructure
extensions.why_it_matters: Improves internal trust and allows early identification of systemic vulnerabilities.
extensions.submission_title: Walking the Narrow Path: Reinforcing AI Governance, Containment, and Trust in the Meta-layer
extensions.submission_overview: This submission draws from Tristan Harris’s 2025 TED talk to underscore the urgency of reinforcing the Meta-layer’s AI-related Desirable Properties. It highlights the existential risks posed by unregulated AI systems and argues for clear implementation protocols in governance, containment, and transparency. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Create anonymous reporting and risk flagging tools for AI interactions.

extensions.title: Transparent Vulnerability Protocols
extensions.why_it_matters: Creates a shared accountability framework and bolsters community trust after breaches.
extensions.submission_title: Security Protocols and Ethical Safeguards in the Lyra System
extensions.submission_overview: This submission distills the architecture and protective mechanisms of the Lyra System—a privacy-centric, emotionally intelligent interface—focusing on its multi-layered approach to identity security, data sovereignty, ethical data handling, and emotional consent. Lyra integrates decentralized identity protocols, local storage autonomy, soulbound emotional markers, and open governance to establish a radically secure and self-protective environment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3
extensions.extension: Combines technical and ethical response pathways with guaranteed community disclosure.

extensions.title: Building Confidence in Whistleblower Systems
extensions.why_it_matters: Visible accountability reassures users that reports lead to meaningful action.
extensions.submission_title: Enhancing Whistleblower Protection within the Meta-Layer
extensions.submission_overview: This submission draws upon established frameworks from WPAC (2015) and Security.org to propose enhancements to whistleblower systems in alignment with the Meta-Layer's Desirable Properties. It emphasizes secure, anonymized federated authentication, user-controlled data sovereignty, interoperable and simplified reporting interfaces, and system-wide transparency and security protocols. These systems are essential to protect whistleblowers from retaliation and to ensure credibility, participation, and systemic accountability. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Provide submission updates and publish anonymized outcome data to show system effectiveness.

extensions.title: Voice and Visibility
extensions.why_it_matters: Reintroducing voice and human discernment in content organization helps rebuild credibility in online navigation, encouraging ethical and accountable information sharing.
extensions.submission_overview: This submission reflects on the current deteriorating state of web search, emphasizing how AI-generated content and algorithmic prioritization have reduced the human-centric experience of exploration. It draws parallels with the early days of Yahoo! and its surfer-driven directories to propose a revival of decentralized, point-of-view-rich human directories. These directories, distributed across communities rather than centralized institutions, can rekindle authentic discovery and trust online. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Trust in modern web search has declined due to hidden ranking criteria and impersonal AI output. Directories created by named individuals or communities, expressing unique voices, offer an alternative trust model based on visible provenance and subjective transparency.

extensions.title: Packet-Level Provenance
extensions.why_it_matters: It shifts the trust boundary from servers and platforms to cryptographically verified assertions made by individuals, enhancing transparency and minimizing systemic trust dependencies.
extensions.submission_title: Towards Decentralized Applications: Rethinking Control Power and Data Exchange in Named-Data Networking
extensions.submission_overview: This submission presents a comprehensive framework and prototype for decentralized applications built on Named-Data Networking (NDN), aimed at resolving centralization in control power over user data, identity, and communications. Through the design, implementation, and evaluation of "NDN Workspace," the work demonstrates how semantic naming, data-centric security, and distributed data synchronization can enable direct, secure, and serverless peer-to-peer collaboration. The study also contributes critical insights into naming schemes, trust schema enforcement, and the broader ecosystem architecture required to support real-time collaborative applications outside the cloud paradigm. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Beyond naming and signature verification, this work implements record-level validation chains where each action can be traced to a user and verified through their certificate lineage.

extensions.title: Real-Time Adversarial Tracking Indicators
extensions.why_it_matters: This creates a responsive and educational layer that cultivates informed digital behavior while countering abusive practices.
extensions.submission_title: AI-Augmented Data Visibility for Safer Web Experiences
extensions.submission_overview: This submission proposes an AI-augmented tool (e.g., a browser extension or embedded prototype) that transparently reveals what data is being collected and tracked during web interactions. It aims to equip users with actionable insight into data flows and help mitigate exploitative ad-based surveillance. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Integrating AI-driven detection of manipulative or excessive tracking behavior with real-time alerts and summaries can extend the Meta-layer's trust framework.

extensions.title: Accreditor-Attestable Verification Layer
extensions.why_it_matters: To gain widespread adoption, especially among conservative institutions, credentials must be both machine-verifiable and humanly trusted. This co-signing mechanism provides a clear audit trail and formal endorsement.
extensions.submission_title: Global Recognition of Prior Learning via Meta-Layer Credentials
extensions.submission_overview: This submission proposes a standardized extension of Recognition of Previous Learning (RPL) by leveraging the badge-based credentialing system of the Meta-Layer. The objective is to create a globally verifiable, interoperable framework that educational institutions can universally recognize, enabling learners to carry validated learning achievements across jurisdictions and systems. The initiative encourages integration with existing academic accreditation bodies while preserving decentralized verification and learner agency. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3
extensions.extension: Adds a feature allowing third-party educational accreditors to digitally co-sign badge authenticity, improving trust in international or high-stakes credential applications.

extensions.title: Scandinavian Journalism as a Pilot Region
extensions.why_it_matters: A low-risk, high-trust context offers an ideal environment for demonstrating the Meta-Layer's power in journalism, with models ready to be replicated globally.
extensions.submission_title: Seeding Generational Familiarity with the Meta-Layer Through Purpose-Driven Educational Use and Scandinavian Journalism Partnerships
extensions.submission_overview: Early Use Case Scandinavian Journalism Newsrooms combined with Seeding Generational Familiarity through Purpose-Driven Use in Education. This submission proposes a dual-entry approach to introduce the Meta-Layer and the Overweb to broad audiences by focusing on two interrelated use cases: education and journalism. First, in the school sector—particularly across Europe—project-based learning environments can integrate Meta-Layer tools to foster youth engagement with a safer, purpose-driven, and participatory web. Second, Scandinavia represents a particularly fertile region for a journalist-specific integration of the Meta-Layer. With strong traditions of collaborative civic culture, peaceful education systems, and relatively depolarized journalism ecosystems, countries like Denmark and Sweden could pioneer the use of a dedicated journalistic layer. This would empower newsrooms to verify content, trace sources, and resist the creep of misinformation. These use cases are mutually reinforcing and could provide a resilient first foothold for broader adoption. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Suggests piloting the Meta-Layer with Scandinavian newsrooms due to civic trust and low polarization, allowing verification tools to enhance newsroom practices and public trust.

extensions.title: Transparent Algorithmic Affordances
extensions.why_it_matters: Algorithmic systems affect user experiences daily. Without accessible transparency mechanisms, users remain disempowered and skeptical, eroding trust.
extensions.submission_title: Humane Design Patterns for Ethical Tech Platforms
extensions.submission_overview: This submission synthesizes practical interface and architectural patterns from the 'Humane Tech Framework' to inform the development of platforms that enhance user agency, attention, relationships, and understanding. The design patterns tackle common harms such as compulsive usage, information overload, and manipulative defaults by emphasizing user wellbeing, transparency, and ethical engagement. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 https://github.com/ErikaOnFire/humane-tech-framework/blob/main/docs/design-patterns.md
extensions.extension: Transparency is enhanced not only by disclosing inputs and models but also by contextualizing algorithmic decisions through user-facing cards that describe why certain content appears. This pattern integrates educational affordances directly into the interface.

extensions.title: Real-time Warnings
extensions.why_it_matters: Immediate and transparent warnings foster informed decision-making, significantly reducing victimization from digital crimes.
extensions.submission_title: AI as the Ultimate Safety Layer
extensions.submission_overview: Digital crimes—scams, phishing, deepfakes, and sophisticated social-engineered fraud—are rapidly escalating in complexity and frequency. Rather than viewing AI as merely exacerbating these threats, this submission proposes an OS-level 'Safety Agent,' a localized AI capable of proactively detecting digital threats, providing mental health interventions, improving personal judgment, and enabling enterprise compliance without compromising privacy. By operating solely on-device and integrated at the operating system level, this solution maximizes data security and user trust. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 Based on article by Scott Belsky: https://www.implications.com/p/the-emergence-of-safety-layers-religion
extensions.extension: The OS-integrated Safety Agent would provide clear, immediate warnings regarding suspected fraudulent or malicious activities, explicitly stating risk levels to users.
